comments.commentBody: The Chinese government's market reforms are built on a shaky scaffold that has one fundamental aim - the maintenance of Party power and privilege, while perpetuating the myth of economic stability and progress.  When the Chinese people awaken to this perilous reality, true economic democratic political reform may finally begin.

For one shot at the Buzzer, I wanted Reggie Miller !!!
Very surprised he was left off the ballot.

I believe there are several other things to consider about Reggie's career numbers:

1. Free Throws - #9 all-time in % and #12 in FT made (no one in the top 30 of FT made has a better percentage). Iced game regardless of the situation.
2. Clutch Ability - There's 1 second left. It's your ball out of bounds, and you're down by 3. There is no player in the history of the game you'd rather have on your team at that scenario.
3. The defense claim: He is 39 steals from the top 30 all-time. Half a season at his pace. He was never a defensive liability.
4. #14 in total points. Compare that to Home Runs. Without steroid-era players, it's the equivalent of Ted Williams or Ernie Banks.
5. His assist numbers are lower because of the offense he played in. His job was to run his defender into the ground, through double screens, catch, and shoot. The only reason for an assist pass was if the low post defender cheated, in which case the point guard usually makes an entry pass to the post. It's an assist caused by Reggie. Check out Mark Jackson's numbers.
6. A career dealing with Smits' bad feet, O'Neal's fragility, management's poor decision making with their enforcer big men (Brad Miller and Antonio Davis) and Ron Artest's difficult battle with mental illness.

My final point: Go back and watch games from his final season. The brawl season. A season that should have been lost. He's 39 with gimpy O'Neal/Tinsley. And he still beats the Celts, and only loses to the Pistons cause Prince has a 7'3" wingspan.

So he hangs it up in the city that loves him, and doesn't go ring-chasing and number-piling when he clearly still could (and had offers to do so). That's a Hall of Famer.
Good CA red / 1974 Beaulieu Vineyards -- Georges de Latour -- Cabernet Sauvignon

Holey Moley. Started as advised in the fourth square of the top row and following "regular crossword symmetry" raced ahead. Until, for reasons that are still unclear, was stopped dead in my tracks at 52A. In my grid was _ _ _n_ _ggl_  _  _. Absolutely nothing. So said "whatever" and moved on to solve several more puzzles. Many, many hours later as non-puzzle spouse was gently removing pages of puzzles to recycling, I was hit by a bus! Morning glory I yelled. Huh! He said. Rescued Paula's grid from the green bin. Entered morning glory and finished in less than a minute. Lovely puzzle Ms. Gamache.

Good puzzle.  I had some troublewith the bottom quadrant, trying to figure out how the word for 59 meant, MAKE OUT, and the word for 58 down fit into the RANCH.  Got it.  I am pretty Pumped up and ready for a bubble bath with Camay surrounded by Morning glories....before tonight's snow hits.

The methodology used in Hans #24, #36 and #37 can be applied to when there are multiple target songs, or the generalized version of Q3. Complication arises when some of the targets are dense, or cluster close together. The order of the target songs being hit matters in that situation. Perhaps that is why in the present version of Q3, there are 101 songs in total and there are only 3 target songs and they are spread out evenly with at least 20 songs in between neighbouring targets. That makes the order of hitting the targets irrelevant to the minimum expected number of button presses, and thus the treatment much easier.

From the standpoint of a political scientist, agribusiness is a prime example of the U.S. government's protection of corporate interests rather than the public interest. There is a public interest, and it is not served by subsidizing unhealthy processed foods.

The brilliance of the corporate strategy of lobbying the government to allow unlabeled GM foods into the entire food supply is that HEALTH EFFECTS CANNOT BE TRACED OR MEASURED. It's easy for corporations to deny potential health impacts when no one can scientifically prove them wrong. We really don't know what we're eating, unless you have the money to buy foods that specifically are labeled as "non-GMO." For decades, the political appointees to the USDA have had cozy ties to industry (to which they immediately return after their short stint as "regulators" of agribusiness), so it isn't shocking that corporate interests would be placed above public health concerns.

We form governments to improve our lives. Our political differences come from a difference in views on the proper role of government (to what extent should government attempt to get involved in any given area, be it social or economic). Whether you advocate a laissez-faire role for government or mistrust corporations' willingness/ability to regulate themselves (their corporate charters will, by law, place profit over competing interests such as public health or environmental protection), I think we can all agree that our government, through more or less regulation, should not ACTIVELY MAKE THINGS WORSE! Our government's subsidization of GM corn (cows weren't meant to eat corn!) and corn-based ethanol (a net LOSS of energy, but no politician dare say so!) contributes directly to processed food as the foundation of the American diet (translation: increased health costs), and, on a wider scale, to increased global food prices (translation: increased global political instability).

I'm no economist, but I can recognize that a higher propensity for diabetes and increased global conflicts have costs that surely offset saving a few cents on the cost of the overly-processed food that I shouldn't be eating anyway.

While it is easy to be cynical in the current political environment, one tool we have left as citizens (human ones, not corporate "citizens") is to SHAME politicians and political appointees into making decisions in the PUBLIC interest through sheer force of numbers. We must not assume that someone else will, and we owe this to future generations who have a right to know what they are eating.
Yes to all four.  No way should GMO foods, even 5% allowed, should not be labeled as such.  Allow the consumer to make an educated choice.  Those who don't care can simply ignore the information.

01. Yes

My concern about this is that same food companies who say that government should keep out and consumer should make the decision, then turn around and refuse to give that information to the consumer while the government just looks the other way. Give me the information and I will make the decision.

I think Americans should become more involved in our food industry in general.  I think some have forgotten that we have the right to decide what kind of food is presented to us and that we do not have to accept everything that is on the shelves.  It seems that so far, that decisions are being made  without regard to what the consumers want.  If we don't have a say in what is being genetically modified, then don't you think that they should at least be labeled?

Yes - Does it bother you that there are genetically engineered ingredients in most of the foods sold in American supermarkets?
Yes - Do you want the products that contain genetically engineered ingredients to be labeled “Contains Genetically Engineered Ingredients”?
Yes - Do you think that government agencies should enact stricter regulations for testing, growing, and marketing of GE crops and other products?
Yes - At this point I'm down to wild salmon.

Being from Idaho I'll talk about sugar beets. We tolerate Monsanto distributing and replacing perfect and natural sugar beet seeds with sugar beet seeds that are genetically modified to be “Round-up ready,” with the intention of replacing all natural seeds. "Roundup ready" seeds have been genetically engineered to permit farmers to drench their crops with Monsanto herbicide without harming the genetically modified crops, but killing all unprotected surrounding crops and plants. Anyone ingesting sugar from these beets is now asked, no , told to eat sugar containing the “Round-up ready” additive and herbicide that would have killed a natural sugar beet.
A recent article in the Idaho Statesman gives readers insight into disturbing facts: A farmer stated if he couldn’t plant Monsanto’s GM sugar beet seeds, conventional seeds would be hard to come by. This tells us that Monsanto can control what we eat and ultimately end natural foods as we know them.
We no longer eat sugar.
The more you know the scarier it gets.
Thank you for passing on this issue.

Hello. I studied plant biology, genetics, & sustainable agriculture at one of the leading agricultural universities in the world, MSU.
In all fairness, these questions are exactly what those opposed to the preservation of organic & heirloom seed & live stock growers want you to ask. Promoters of GMO's know that once the pollen of a GMO crosses with an organic or an heirloom, it is lost forever. The current legal system favors those who own the copyright to the GMO, even claiming legal ownership to seedstock that maybe an heirloom or an organic that has cross pollinated. There are many other complex legal & ethical questions that this simple survey fails to address. GMO companies want you to believe that they are merely altering traits of the plant such as disease resistances but the vast majority of plants have been altered to only grow when an expensive chemical is sprayed on the plant, ensuring totally dependency on products such as Roundup. Imagine the nightmare this has caused for organic or heirloom growers that raise their own seedstock. GMO pollen has contaminated Mexico's ancient seed stock and threatens other crops such as sugar beets & alfalfa. These GMO plants only grow by chemical spray applications that include pesticides & herbicides, not altered traits. Those who attempt to promote foods derived from GMO's by arguing label issues & avoiding the true nature of the plants genetic alteration continue to muddle the water of a populace that has shied away from scientific reason & ethical responsibility.

It would be difficult for anyone to write a more one-sided article than this one. The foundation error is the claim Apple has a monopoly in anything. The company is a market leader in only one of the half-dozen fields it participates in - selling music. Even there, it is not a monopoly, which requires controlling entry to a market and subverting competition. The iPod leads among music players, but the iPod touch is really a part of the general multimedia and communications device market. Again, Apple does nothing to stifle competition.

Second, it is important to understand Google and Apple are selling different things with their subscription markets. Google's subscriptions are for reading in a browser, while Apple's are for apps. That makes the former less valuable. Google does not already have an established base of thousands of content using iPad apps to manage and promote. Apple does. Google also does not offer the number of affluent potential subscribers Apple does. Clearly, the additional 20% charged by Apple pays for important attributes.

Last, but not least, Google has another way of making money in addition to the 10% fee. It, unlike Apple, will not allow subscribers to keep their personal details and data private. Instead our identities and interests will be mined for Google ads and resold to data merchants. That may be worth more to Google than 20% more in fees from publishers.

These are fundamental differences between the two platforms this article fails to address. One cannot think seriously about the topic without considering them.

The 30% cut that Apple takes is not at all onerous compared to the revenue split typically required in a retail outlet, there the retailer takes between 50% to 70%. These publishers that complain are not being honest. As for the user data that they are clamouring for -  often this is sold to a 3rd party for junk mail use or so that they can up sell or cross sell to the subscriber, this is no great loss to the customer. They also use the data to sell advertising space, although they wont get a demographic break down from Apple. surely they'll still get numbers?
